The good fight is ended at the Hopkins as far as Dr Broadus Mitchell
is concerned. For two decades one of the community's most beloved citizens,
he has brought nobility and warmth of spirit into the cold places of the
University. His departure will leave a vacant place among us.
We can't speak of Dr Mitchell.as the scholar that he is. His articles
and researches, his reputation among American economists belong to a
world of which undergraduates are only dimly aware. Even his textbooks
that we use reflect but meagerly the individual.
The memory of him that will linger with us is filled with vanished
classrooms ringing with laughter, with discussion circles and speeches
warmed by good-humored pugnacity, with the twinkle of his inquisitive
blue eye5.
Dr Mitchell's roots lie deep in the University's tradition. The friendly,
unvindicative war that he waged so long against society's enemies and
restrictions has symbolized freedom as much as the pillars of Gilman hall.
The fight of every liberal was his fight, and conservatives, if objecting to
him for it, were forced to love him as well. What he did was done to the
utmost of his ability.
But even after the black letters are rubbed from his office door, Hopkins
won't forget. If no plaques are erected in his memory, other monuments
will longer endure. He is a man of good will, and there are twenty-five
generations of Hopkins men who will number his among their friends.

The NEWS-LETTER is taking no definite stand for
any one of the candidates
for the Council presidency
this year. A service can be

the analysis of the platforms
which the candidates have set forth. To a large-portion of the campus, these are the sole means for judging the candidates. All three men: Butt, Thaler, newlyentered in the race, and Williams are juniors in good
standing, with a sufficient number of activities to insure
their interest in campus life and doings.
There is much in common in all three platforms,
though the wording or terms are in certain cases carefully coached in generalities. All three men seem to
favor the proposed amendment, revising representation
on the Council. This seems most satisfactory from any
viewpoint. All three candidates further approve of
the various measures passed this year, designed to
afford a closer student check on Council activity: open
meetings, discussion, recall, referendum. This, too, is
as it should be.
Thaler makes no mention of further extension of

take with a grain of salt. We're willing to bet our
bottom dollar that there'll be no further Council control. Finances, for one thing, are still a little beyond
the Council's capabilities, and we doubt that Dean
Berry is particularly anxious to entrust activities any
further to student jurisdiction. This much can be deemphasized in all the platforms, if not entirely forgotten for this election at least. It looks good but
doesn't mean anything.

To the Editor:
The sentiment of the student body
on Dr Mitchell's resignation is already so well-known, that it requires
no further comment. It has manifested itself in editorials in the
NEWS-LETTER, and in letters to Dr
Mitchell and to the administration.
It seems to me, however, that the
attitude of the administration in accepting Dr Mitchell's resignation is
a questionable one. One of ,the primary functions of the governing
body of a university is to secure men
who are capable scholars and instructors for the professorial staff.
Dr Mitchell certainly fits into this
classification. He is outstanding in
his field. To many of his students he
was not only a capable instructor,
but also a stimulating personality
and an inspiring individual. Therefore, I feel that the administration
of the University should have made
every possible effort to persuade Dr
Mitchell to continue his valuable
work at Johns Hopkins, even to the
point of not accepting his resignation. It might have required compromise, but it would have been worth
while if Dr Mitchell had been persuaded to remain here.
Perhaps it is not yet too late.
Edwin J. Oppenheimer '41

"Grand Illusion" comes
to Baltimore tomorrow
Starting Saturday, April 22, the Little Theatre
will present the Baltimore Premiere of the long-awaited
international film triumph, Grand Illusion. It was produced in France by Jean Renoir, and stars Eric von
Stroheim, Pierre Fresnay, Jean Gabin and Dita Parlo.
Grand Illusion comes to Baltimore bearing the plaudits
of the nation's critics. The National Board of Review
seelcted it as "The best film of the year 1938," and the
New York film critics gave it the first prize as the "best
foreign film of the year 1938."
Grand Illusion is a war story without war scenes. It
is a tale of human beings rather than of battles, and
deals with the effect of war on the lives of the individuals engaged in it. It is a prison camp story of the war,
based on director Jean Renior's own experiences. The
theme concerns itself with the simple humanities that
are stronger than man-made wars; more enduring than
frontiers.
The story is an original one by Jean Renoir (who is a
son of the famous impressionist painter and was) adapted by the author and Charles Spaak. There are complete
dialogue titles in English. For its direction, Renoir received the Cross of the Legion of Honor from the French
government. He is the only director in the world to be
thus honored.
Grand Illusion is a celluloid textbook that describes
the history men live—not the history that is described
by those who watch, criticize, or moralize. It does not,
except by reference, condemn warfare. It merely tells
about it in terms of the human beings who die in it. We
hope for propaganda it carries will be remembered, if
another kind of propaganda is tooted from a bugle to
make men leave their brains as a deposit for a uniform.
—J. M. V.

members of the varsity track team.
